description:
**Nvidia Triton**

This dashboard provides insights into your Nvidia Triton Server. You can use this dashbaord to check resource consumption in GPU and CPU. You can also use it to get in depth look at your inference requests per model and cache stats(if enabled).

**Useful Links**

* [Integration Docs]()
title: Nvidia Triton Overview

definition.content:
**NVIDIA Triton**

This dashboard provides an overview of your Triton Inference Server. It monitors inference request status, model inferencing latency, cache activities, and GPU/CPU usage from inferencing.

**Useful Links**
- [Nvidia Triton Integration doc](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/nvidia_triton/?tab=host)
- [AI Stack Integrations blog](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/ai-integrations/)
- [Nvidia Triton metric collection](https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/triton-inference-server/user-guide/docs/user_guide/metrics.html)

The service checks show the OpenMetrics endpoint status along with the Triton server health status.

The monitor summary shows you any active alerts for the most crucial Nvidia Triton Metrics.
GPU memory usage for your Triton server shows up here grouped by the GPU UID and host
The graphs below show the GPU power on your Triton server and the actual usage versus the power limits.

CPU Metrics are only supported on Linux. 
They collect information from the /proc filesystem.
*Counts:* The following graphs show the Triton server inference numbers, such as failure, success, and pending, along with total count and batch execution
*Latencies*: The following graphs show the Triton server latency durations, such as request, queue, and computation.
The following graph shows the cache metrics reported by Triton directly, such as the cache hit/miss counts and durations.

definition.title: Number of responses stored in response cache
Number of cache evictions in response cache
Number of cache lookups in response cache
Number of cache misses in response cache
Number of cache hits in response cache
